questions.question: The primary tax advantage of incentive stock options (ISOs) over nonqualified stock options (NSOs) is:

options.A: ISOs have no holding period requirement
options.B: ISO exercises do not create regular tax income (though may trigger AMT)
options.C: ISOs can be granted to consultants

questions.explanation: ISOs don't create regular tax income at exercise (only AMT preference). Gain is recognized at sale and may qualify for long-term capital gain if holding requirements are met. NSOs create ordinary income at exercise equal to the spread, subject to income and employment taxes.
questions.tip: ISO = no regular tax at exercise (AMT may apply). NSO = ordinary income at exercise. ISOs have holding requirements.

questions.question: Section 409A governs:

options.B: Nonqualified deferred compensation arrangements

questions.explanation: Section 409A imposes strict rules on nonqualified deferred compensation, including election timing (generally before the year of service) and distribution triggers (separation, disability, death, change in control, fixed dates, or unforeseeable emergencies). Violations result in immediate income inclusion plus 20% penalty and interest.
questions.tip: Section 409A = NQDC rules. Strict election/distribution timing. 20% penalty + interest for violations.

questions.question: Personal use of a company-provided vehicle is:

options.B: Taxable income to the employee
options.D: Tax-free if used more than 50% for business

questions.explanation: Personal use of a company car is taxable compensation. The value must be included in the employee's income and is subject to federal income tax, FICA, and FUTA. Several IRS-approved methods can be used to value the benefit: annual lease value, cents-per-mile, or commuting value.
questions.tip: Company car personal use = taxable. Use IRS valuation methods. Report on W-2.

questions.question: Restricted stock units (RSUs) are taxed when:

options.B: The employee makes an 83(b) election
options.C: They vest and shares are delivered

questions.explanation: RSUs are taxed as ordinary income when they vest and shares are delivered. The taxable amount is the fair market value at vesting. Unlike restricted stock, Section 83(b) elections are not available for RSUs because the employee doesn't own property until delivery.
questions.tip: RSUs = taxed at vesting when shares delivered. No 83(b) election available (no property until delivery).

questions.question: Section 162(m) limits the corporate deduction for compensation paid to covered employees to:
questions.explanation: Section 162(m) limits the deduction for compensation paid to 'covered employees' of publicly held corporations to $1 million per year. After TCJA, this applies to the CEO, CFO, and top three other officers, with no exception for performance-based pay.
questions.tip: Section 162(m) = $1M cap on deductible pay for covered employees. Performance-based exception eliminated by TCJA.

questions.question: Golden parachute payments are subject to:

options.B: A 20% excise tax on excess payments and loss of corporate deduction

questions.explanation: Excess parachute payments (change-in-control payments exceeding 3× base compensation) are subject to a 20% excise tax paid by the recipient, and the corporation loses its deduction for the excess amounts. Base amount is the average of the prior 5 years' W-2 compensation.
questions.tip: Golden parachutes: 20% excise on excess (amount > 3× base). No deduction for excess. Applies to change-in-control payments.

questions.question: To receive favorable long-term capital gain treatment on ISO stock, the employee must hold the stock for:

options.B: At least 2 years from grant AND 1 year from exercise

questions.explanation: For ISO stock to qualify for long-term capital gain treatment on sale, it must be held: (1) more than 2 years from the option grant date, AND (2) more than 1 year from exercise. Selling earlier (disqualifying disposition) converts gain to ordinary income.
questions.tip: ISO holding: 2 years from grant + 1 year from exercise. Disqualifying disposition = ordinary income.

questions.question: A Section 83(b) election is beneficial when:

options.A: The stock is expected to decline in value
options.B: The stock is expected to significantly appreciate
options.C: The employee plans to forfeit the stock
options.D: The employee is in the highest tax bracket

questions.explanation: An 83(b) election includes restricted stock in income at grant (when typically worth less). If the stock appreciates significantly, all post-election appreciation is capital gain (not ordinary income). Risk: if forfeited or stock declines, no deduction for previously-taxed amount.
questions.tip: 83(b) = pay tax now at low value, future appreciation = capital gain. Risk: forfeit or decline = no refund.

questions.question: A rabbi trust used in nonqualified deferred compensation:

options.B: Provides income deferral while protecting assets from employer use (but not creditors)

questions.explanation: Rabbi trusts hold NQDC assets in an irrevocable trust, protecting from employer misuse. However, assets remain subject to employer creditors in bankruptcy (required for tax deferral). The employee has no current income because the promise is unsecured against creditors.
questions.tip: Rabbi trust: assets protected from employer, but subject to employer's creditors. Maintains tax deferral.

questions.question: A qualified employee stock purchase plan (ESPP) allows employees to purchase stock at a discount of up to:

options.B: 10% of fair market value

questions.explanation: Qualified ESPPs (Section 423) allow employees to purchase employer stock at up to a 15% discount from fair market value. The discount is not taxed at purchase. Holding period requirements (2 years from offering, 1 year from purchase) affect the character of gain at sale.
questions.tip: ESPP: up to 15% discount. Discount not taxed at purchase. Holding requirements for favorable treatment.

questions.question: When an NSO is exercised, the employer receives a deduction equal to:

options.B: The fair market value of the stock at exercise
options.C: The spread (FMV minus exercise price) - the employee's ordinary income

questions.explanation: When an NSO is exercised, the employer receives a compensation deduction equal to the spread (FMV at exercise minus exercise price) - the same amount the employee includes as ordinary income. The employer's deduction matches the employee's income inclusion.
questions.tip: NSO: employer deduction = employee's ordinary income (the spread). Matching treatment.

questions.question: Under Section 162(m) after TCJA, 'covered employees' include:

options.B: The CEO, CFO, and the three highest-paid officers
options.D: Only officers who are also directors

questions.explanation: Post-TCJA, covered employees include the CEO, CFO, and the three highest-compensated officers (other than CEO and CFO). Once an employee becomes a covered employee, they remain so for future years (even after separation). The $1 million limit applies to each individually.
questions.tip: Covered employees: CEO + CFO + top 3 others. Once covered, always covered (even after leaving).

questions.question: Under Section 409A, distributions from nonqualified deferred compensation can be made upon all of the following EXCEPT:

options.B: Change in control
options.C: At the employee's request at any time

questions.explanation: Section 409A limits distributions to six permissible events: separation from service, disability, death, change in control, unforeseeable emergency, and specified time/fixed schedule. Distributions cannot occur simply at the employee's request - that would trigger immediate taxation plus penalties.
questions.tip: 409A distribution triggers: separation, death, disability, change in control, fixed date, emergency. No 'at will' distributions.

questions.question: De minimis fringe benefits are excludable from income because:

options.A: They are provided to all employees equally
options.B: They are so small that accounting for them is administratively impractical
options.D: They are provided by nonprofit employers

questions.explanation: De minimis fringes are property or services whose value is so small that accounting for them would be unreasonable or administratively impractical. Examples include occasional personal use of copy machine, coffee, snacks, occasional meals, and flowers for illness. Cash is never de minimis.
questions.tip: De minimis = too small to track. Coffee, snacks, occasional meals. Cash is NEVER de minimis.

questions.question: Stock appreciation rights (SARs) provide the employee with:

options.A: The right to purchase stock at a fixed price
options.B: The increase in stock value without actually purchasing stock
options.D: Guaranteed returns regardless of stock price

questions.explanation: SARs give employees the right to receive the appreciation in stock value (difference between grant price and current FMV) in cash or stock, without requiring the employee to purchase shares. Taxed as ordinary income when exercised/settled.
questions.tip: SARs = stock appreciation without buying. Settles in cash or shares. Ordinary income at settlement.

questions.question: Compensation clawback provisions allow companies to:

options.B: Recover previously paid compensation in certain circumstances

questions.explanation: Clawback provisions allow companies to recover previously paid compensation, typically after a financial restatement or misconduct. Dodd-Frank requires public companies to have clawback policies for incentive compensation based on misstated financials. Tax treatment of recovered amounts is complex.
questions.tip: Clawbacks: recover comp after restatement/misconduct. Dodd-Frank requires for public companies. Tax issues on recovery.

questions.question: The annual limit on ISOs that can vest for the first time in any year is:
questions.explanation: ISOs are limited to $100,000 in aggregate fair market value (measured at grant) that can first become exercisable in any calendar year. Amounts exceeding this limit are automatically treated as NSOs. This limit is per employee across all ISO grants.
questions.tip: ISO $100K/year vesting limit (FMV at grant). Excess converts to NSO treatment.

questions.question: A Section 83(b) election must be filed within:

options.B: 30 days of grant
options.D: By the due date of the tax return

questions.explanation: An 83(b) election must be filed with the IRS within 30 days of the property transfer (grant). This is a strict deadline - late elections are invalid. A copy should be provided to the employer and attached to the tax return. There is no extension available.
questions.tip: 83(b) = 30 days from grant. Strict deadline, no extensions. File with IRS, employer, and attach to return.

questions.question: A supplemental executive retirement plan (SERP) is typically used to:

options.B: Provide retirement benefits above qualified plan limits

questions.explanation: SERPs provide retirement benefits beyond qualified plan limits (Section 415 limits). They are nonqualified plans that can discriminate in favor of executives. Benefits are unfunded promises (subject to creditors), and the employer receives no deduction until the executive receives payment.
questions.tip: SERP = retirement benefits above qualified limits. Nonqualified, unfunded, can favor executives.

questions.question: Phantom stock provides employees with:

options.B: A contractual right to receive cash equal to the value of a specified number of shares
options.D: Dividends on stock they don't own

questions.explanation: Phantom stock is a contractual arrangement giving employees the right to receive cash (or sometimes stock) equal to the value of a specified number of shares at vesting or payout. No actual stock ownership occurs. Taxed as ordinary income when paid, subject to Section 409A.
questions.tip: Phantom stock = cash value mimicking stock ownership. No actual shares. Ordinary income treatment. 409A applies.

questions.question: The 'base amount' for golden parachute calculations is:

options.B: The average annual W-2 compensation for the 5 years preceding the change in control
options.C: Three times the employee's base salary
options.D: Total compensation in the year of the change

questions.explanation: The base amount is the average of the employee's annualized includible compensation (W-2 wages plus certain other amounts) for the 5 taxable years preceding the change in control. Parachute payments exceeding 3× the base amount trigger the excise tax and deduction disallowance.
questions.tip: Base amount = average W-2 over prior 5 years. Excess over 3× base triggers 20% excise + no deduction.

questions.question: Early exercise of stock options (before vesting) combined with an 83(b) election:

options.B: Converts the option to an RSU
options.C: Allows the employee to start the capital gains holding period early on restricted stock
options.D: Eliminates all taxes on the stock

questions.explanation: Some plans allow early exercise of unvested options. Combined with an 83(b) election on the resulting restricted stock, this starts the capital gains holding period immediately (at typically low values) and converts future appreciation to capital gain. Risk: forfeiture results in no refund of tax paid.
questions.tip: Early exercise + 83(b): start capital gains clock early. Powerful for startups. Risk: forfeit stock but already paid tax.

questions.question: Section 457(b) plans for government employees differ from 457(b) plans for tax-exempt organizations in that:

options.B: Government plan assets are held in trust and protected from creditors
options.C: Tax-exempt organization plans have no contribution limits
options.D: Only tax-exempt organization plans are subject to 409A

questions.explanation: Government 457(b) plan assets must be held in trust for employees (protected from employer creditors). Tax-exempt organization 457(b) plans cannot be funded - they are unfunded promises subject to employer creditors, similar to NQDC. This difference affects security and taxation.
questions.tip: Gov't 457(b) = funded trust, protected. Tax-exempt 457(b) = unfunded, subject to creditors. Major difference.

questions.question: Section 83(i), added by TCJA, allows certain employees to defer tax on stock compensation for up to:

options.B: 3 years

questions.explanation: Section 83(i) allows employees of eligible private companies to elect to defer income from exercising stock options or settling RSUs for up to 5 years (or earlier if stock becomes publicly traded, employee separates, etc.). Strict eligibility requirements: 80% employee coverage, non-executives, private company.
questions.tip: Section 83(i): 5-year deferral for private company stock comp. Strict eligibility: 80% coverage, non-execs only.

questions.question: A safe harbor from the golden parachute rules (Section 280G) is available if:

options.A: Parachute payments are approved by 75% of shareholders
options.B: The employee was not a 'disqualified individual'
options.C: The company is a small business corporation (S corp) and payments are approved by shareholder vote

questions.explanation: S corporations and certain private corporations can avoid 280G by obtaining shareholder approval. The safe harbor requires: (1) complete disclosure, (2) approval by more than 75% of shareholders (by voting power), and (3) no stock held by the disqualified individual or related party votes.
questions.tip: 280G safe harbor for private/S corps: 75%+ shareholder approval after full disclosure. Disqualified individual can't vote.

questions.question: The AMT preference item for ISO exercise equals:

options.A: The fair market value of the stock at exercise
options.B: The exercise price paid
options.C: The spread (FMV minus exercise price) at exercise

questions.explanation: For AMT purposes, ISO exercise creates a preference item equal to the spread (excess of FMV over exercise price) at exercise. This can trigger AMT liability in the exercise year. The AMT basis is FMV, so the AMT preference reverses when the stock is sold.
questions.tip: ISO AMT preference = spread at exercise. May trigger AMT. Creates AMT credit for future use.

questions.question: A secular trust differs from a rabbi trust in that:

options.A: Secular trusts provide no tax deferral - assets are taxable when contributed
options.B: Secular trusts are only for religious organizations
options.C: Secular trusts have no funding requirements
options.D: Secular trusts are subject to Section 409A

questions.explanation: Secular trusts protect assets from employer AND employer's creditors, giving employees a secured interest. However, this security causes immediate taxation when contributions are made (constructive receipt). Secular trusts sacrifice tax deferral for asset protection.
questions.tip: Secular trust = protected from employer's creditors BUT taxable when funded. Security vs. deferral tradeoff.

questions.question: A disqualifying disposition of ESPP shares results in:

options.A: All gain treated as capital gain
options.B: The discount element treated as ordinary income and remaining gain as capital gain
options.C: All gain treated as ordinary income

questions.explanation: A disqualifying disposition (sale before 2 years from offering or 1 year from purchase) requires ordinary income recognition of the discount (FMV at purchase minus purchase price), reported as W-2 wages. Any additional gain or loss is capital gain/loss.
questions.tip: ESPP disqualifying disposition: discount = ordinary income (W-2). Additional gain = capital. Qualifying = limited ordinary income.

questions.question: Repricing underwater stock options (reducing exercise price) can result in:

options.B: The repriced option being treated as a new grant, potentially triggering Section 409A issues

questions.explanation: Repricing creates a new option grant for tax purposes. If the new exercise price is below FMV at repricing, the option may be treated as deferred compensation subject to Section 409A, resulting in immediate income inclusion plus 20% penalty. Exchange programs require careful structuring.
questions.tip: Option repricing = new grant. If below FMV = 409A disaster (immediate tax + 20%). Use exchange programs carefully.

questions.question: The short-term deferral exception to Section 409A applies when payment is made by:

options.A: December 31 of the year the compensation is earned
options.B: March 15 of the year following the year the compensation vests (2½ months)
options.C: June 30 of the year following vesting

questions.explanation: The short-term deferral exception exempts arrangements from Section 409A if payment is made by the 15th day of the 3rd month (March 15 for calendar year taxpayers) following the later of: (1) the end of the fiscal year in which the right vests, or (2) the end of the calendar year in which the right vests.
questions.tip: Short-term deferral: pay by March 15 after vesting year = not 409A deferred comp. Common for annual bonuses.

questions.question: An ISO granted to a more-than-10% shareholder must have:

options.A: An exercise price at least 110% of FMV and a term of 5 years or less
options.B: An exercise price at FMV and a term of 10 years or less

questions.explanation: ISOs granted to employees owning more than 10% of the company must have: (1) an exercise price of at least 110% of FMV at grant, and (2) a maximum term of 5 years (vs. 10 years for other employees). These stricter requirements prevent excessive benefits to major shareholders.
questions.tip: ISO to >10% owner: 110% of FMV exercise price, max 5-year term. More restrictive than regular ISOs.

questions.question: A Section 125 cafeteria plan allows employees to:

options.B: Choose between cash and qualified benefits on a pre-tax basis

questions.explanation: Section 125 cafeteria plans allow employees to choose between taxable cash and qualified non-taxable benefits (health insurance, FSA, dependent care). Elections are made pre-tax. Irrevocable elections must be made before the plan year begins (with limited exceptions for status changes).
questions.tip: Cafeteria plan: pre-tax choice between cash and benefits. Must elect before year begins. Status change exceptions.

questions.question: Stock option compensation for covered employees under Section 162(m):

options.A: Is exempt from the $1 million limit
options.B: Is fully subject to the $1 million limit with no exemptions
options.D: Creates no deduction for the employer

questions.explanation: After TCJA, all compensation to covered employees is subject to the $1 million limit - the performance-based exemption was eliminated. Stock option spread income counts toward the limit in the year of exercise. Companies may lose deductions on large equity payouts to executives.
questions.tip: Post-TCJA: all comp counts toward $1M 162(m) limit. No performance-based exception. Big impact on equity compensation.

questions.question: Under Section 409A, distributions upon separation from service to a 'specified employee' of a public company must be delayed:

options.B: 90 days

questions.explanation: Specified employees (top 50 highest-paid officers of public companies, subject to income threshold) cannot receive 409A distributions upon separation until 6 months after separation or death. This prevents executives from timing separation to accelerate deferred compensation.
questions.tip: 409A 6-month delay for specified employees (top officers) on separation. Public companies. Death exception applies.

questions.question: An ISO can become an NSO in all of the following situations EXCEPT:

options.A: The $100,000 annual vesting limit is exceeded
options.B: The option is transferred to a family member
options.C: The employee terminates and exercises more than 3 months after termination
options.D: The employee holds the resulting stock past the ISO holding period

questions.explanation: ISOs convert to NSOs when: exceeding the $100,000 vesting limit, transferring the option, exercising more than 3 months after termination (1 year for disability), or modifying terms. Holding stock past the holding period doesn't convert the option - it just enables favorable capital gains treatment.
questions.tip: ISO → NSO: >$100K vest, transfer, late exercise, modification. Holding stock longer = good (LTCG treatment).
